intro: Salicornia herbacea var. mysuroides, commonly known as marsh samphire, is a halophytic plant adapted to grow in saline and brackish environments. It is characterized by its fleshy, succulent stems and leaves that are often covered in a waxy cuticle to reduce water loss. This variety typically grows in coastal marshes, estuaries, and salt marshes, where it thrives in high-salinity soils. Its small, greenish flowers are clustered in dense spikes, and it produces small, edible seeds. The plant plays an important role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various wildlife species.
